data.title: Woody Allen Has Zero Regrets About Calling Himself the “Poster Boy” for #MeToo
data.meta_description: The director says he’s “done everything that the #MeToo movement would love to achieve.”
data.text:
Woody Allen has no regrets about a controversial statement he made in 2018 about how he believes he should be the “poster boy” for the #MeToo movement. Amazon later cited these comments, which earned backlash at the time, in its defense when Allen sued the streamer for $68 million.

Still, Allen recently told France 24 that he stands by his words: “I should be” the movement’s poster boy, he reiterated.

“Not at all,” he replied when asked if he regretted those remarks. “I’ve worked with hundreds of actresses, not one of them has ever complained about me; not a single complaint. I’ve employed women in the top capacities, in every capacity. For years we’ve always paid them exactly the equal of men. I’ve done everything that the #MeToo movement would love to achieve.”

Allen originally made his remarks in a 2018 interview with Argentine journalist Jorge Lanata. “I’m a big advocate of the #MeToo movement,” Allen said at the time. “I feel when they find people who harass innocent women and men, it’s a good thing that they’re exposing them. But you know I, I should be the poster boy for the #MeToo movement, because I have worked in movies for 50 years. I’ve worked with hundreds of actresses, hundreds, and not a single one—big ones, famous ones, ones starting out—have ever, ever, not a single one, ever suggested any kind of impropriety at all.”

Dylan Farrow, Allen’s estranged adopted daughter, has long accused him of sexually molesting her as a child. Allen has repeatedly denied the claims. Still, Farrow’s allegations have earned her support from actors like Natalie Portman and Reese Witherspoon. Actors like Colin Firth and Ellen Page have said they will no longer work with Allen in the future, though not every member of Hollywood’s A-list has turned against him; actor Scarlett Johansson, for instance, recently threw her support behind Allen. “I love Woody,” she told the Hollywood Reporter this week. “I believe him, and I would work with him anytime.”

Farrow penned a quick response to Johansson on Twitter following the THR story. “Because if we’ve learned anything from the past two years it’s that you definitely should believe male predators who ‘maintain their innocence’ without question,” she wrote. “Scarlett has a long way to go in understanding the issue she claims to champion.”

Allen sat down for the France 24 interview to promote his film A Rainy Day in New York, starring Timothée Chalamet and Elle Fanning. Both stars have since distanced themselves from the project, which was dropped by Amazon and later picked up by international distributors; it made its debut this summer in Poland. Allen is currently embroiled in a $68 million lawsuit against Amazon, after the streamer broke off its four-picture agreement with the director. Amazon has named Allen‘s #MeToo comments as part of the reason the company could no longer work with the polarizing director.

In the France 24 interview, Allen shrugged off concerns that he has lost the favor of Hollywood. “I couldn’t care less,” he said. “I’ve never worked in Hollywood, I always work in New York…. If tomorrow nobody would finance my films and nobody would finance my theater plays or nobody would publish my books or anything, I’d still get up and write because that’s what I do. I will always work. What happens to it commercially is another matter.”
